title: The historical writing on this subject is vast, even in English. Among the most useful of the general works are: G
The World Encompassed: The First European Maritime Empires, c. 800–1650
which contains helpful chapters on the Vikings, Genoese and Venetians as well as the Portuguese, Spanish, Dutch, French and English; the somewhat dated but still very important studies by
The Discovery of the Sea
The Age of Reconnaissance: Discovery, Exploration and Settlement, 1450 to 1650
Dan O'Sullivan, The Age of Discovery, 1400–1550

Elliott's classic account of the impact of the discovery of America on Europe, The Old World and the New, 1492–1650 (Cambridge, Cambridge University Press, 1972).

A Short History of the Destruction of the Indies

For Asia one might begin with The Travels of Marco Polo (available in many editions including one from Penguin Books). Extensive contemporary, especially Portuguese, material is incorporated into Donald F. Lach, Asia in the Making of Europe (Chicago

also published in four separate editions for India, Southeast Asia, China and Japan. English navigators, sea captains and adventurers are celebrated in Richard Hakluyt, Voyages and Discoveries: The Principal Navigations, Voyages, Traffques ana Discoveries of the English Nation

Among other kinds of sources, maps are invaluable guides to the course of events in this period, not least the voyages of discovery themselves: The Times Atlas of World History (London, HarperCollins, various editions) is one of the best and most clearly illustrated sources for this purpose, but it can be usefully supplemented by Francis Robinson

note: Cipolla, European Culture and Overseas Expansion (Harmondsworth, Penguin, 1970)) Geoffrey Parker, The Military Revolution: Military Innovation and the Rise of the West, 1500-1800 (Cambridge, Cambridge University Press, 1988);

see, for this, especially Alfred W. Crosby's two works, The Columbian Exchange: Biological and Cultural Consequences of 1492 (Westport, Connecticut, Greenwood Press, 1972), and Ecological Imperialisms The Biological Expansion of Europe, 900—1900
title: To this might be added, especially on cartography, Eviatar Zerubavel, Terra Cognita: The Mental Discovery of America

Parry's studies, cited earlier, there have been some incisive accounts of the role of military and naval technology in the early history of European expansion, among them the chapter on 'Guns and Sails Overseas' in Carlo M
'Western Arms in Maritime Asia in the Early Phases of Expansion'
But one might now wish to qualify these accounts with the impact of disease and environmental factors

container-title: 'Prince Henry and the Origins of Portuguese Expansion'
title: The curious history of Prester John, 'a man who never existed', is considered in Alistair Lamb, 'Prester John'
There is a valuable account of Henry 'the Navigator' and his historical interpretation by Malyn Newitt

container-title: and for Asia and the Portuguese Sanjay Subrahmanyam, The Portuguese Empire in Asia, 1500—1700: A Political ana Economic History (London, Longman, 1993). An informative source for the early history of the Dutch and English East India Companies is Om Prakash, European Commercial Enterprise is Pre-Colonial India
note: part 5 of the New Cambridge History of India) (Cambridge, Cambridge University Press, 1998), and though it relates to a somewhat later period, there is also Holden Furber's masterly Rival Empires of Trade in the Orient, 1600-1800 (Minneapolis, University of Minneapolis Press, 1976).

that take into account recent historical work on the slave trade. Among the many regional studies for this period for the Americas, see Edwin Williamson, The Penguin History of Latin America (Harmondsworth, Penguin, 1992
